metadata.title: The "Automatic Updates" service should be enabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "Automatic Updates" service is used for verification and installation of new patches, hot fixes and Service Packs. This service searches the Microsoft web site for these updates. It is recommended that this service be enabled to perform the download and installation of updates to the operational system. In order to avoid problems caused by the installation of patches that are unnecessary or incompatible with existing applications, it is recommended to enable the warning that alerts the user of the installation.

criterion.comment: 'Automatic Updates' must be enabled.

metadata.title: The "Messenger" service should be disabled in Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "Messenger" service is used to send messages between clients and servers. This service can also be used to send messages to a computer on the Internet. It is recommended that this service be disabled, whenever possible, so as to avoid "Denial of Service" attacks, when sending a large quantity of messages to the receiving computer may cause system unavailability.

criterion.comment: Check if 'Messenger' Service key exist.
The service 'Messenger' must be disabled.

metadata.title: The "Audit account logon events" parameter should be set to "Success" and "Failure".
metadata.description: The "Audit account logon events" parameter is used to log events related to the authentication of local users via a client computer. It is recommended that this type of event be recorded, to help administrators gather information about which users are being authenticated or attempting to do so. This parameter also helps identify Denial-of-Service attack attempts, where an attacker makes numerous requests for authentication until the computer can no longer process them and becomes unavailable.

criterion.comment: 'Audit account logon events' must be configured as 'Success' and 'Failure'.

metadata.title: The "Audit account management" parameter should be set to "Success" and "Failure".
metadata.description: The "Audit account management" parameter is used to log events related to the management of user accounts. It is recommended that these events be recorded, to help administrators collect information about the success or failure in the creation, removal or alteration of user accounts.

criterion.comment: 'Audit account management' must be configured as 'Success' and 'Failure'.

metadata.title: The "Audit logon events" parameter should be set to "Success" and "Failure".
metadata.description: The "Audit logon events" parameter is used to record events involved either in the network sessions' opening/closing process or in system logins and logouts. These types of events should be audited, to help administrators gather information about users who log on to the system.

criterion.comment: 'Audit logon events' must be configured as 'Success' and 'Failure'.

metadata.title: The "Audit object access" parameter should be set to "Failure".
metadata.description: The "Audit object access" parameter is used to log events that refer to the handling of system objects, such as directories, files, Registry keys, printers and others. Failed attempts to access these objects should be audited, as these can reveal access attempts by unauthorized users. Only objects that have had their "System Access Control List" ("SACL") defined will be audited.

criterion.comment: 'Audit object access' must be configured as 'Failure'.

metadata.title: The "Audit policy change" parameter should be set to "Success" and "Failure".
metadata.description: The "Audit policy change" parameter is used to log events that involve on one-hand changes to, and the assignment of user rights and privileges or, on the other hand, changes to the audit configuration. As the configuration of these aspects of the security policy should be restricted to authorized administrators only, attempts (successful or failed) to alter them should be audited.

criterion.comment: 'Audit policy change' must be configured as 'Success' and 'Failure'.

metadata.title: The "Audit privilege use" parameter should be set to "Failure".
metadata.description: The "Audit privilege use" parameter is used to log events that involve the use of user rights. When enabled, all user rights are audited except for the following: "Bypass Traverse Checking", "Debug Programs", "Create a Token Object", "Replace Process Level Token", "Generate Security Audits", "Backup Files and Directories" and "Restore Files and Directories". When set to audit both successful and failed attempts, this type of auditing creates a very large number of entries in the log file. For this reason, it should be set to log only events that have failed.

criterion.comment: 'Audit privilege use' must be configured as 'Failure'.

metadata.title: The "Audit process tracking" parameter should be configured with all the options cleared.
metadata.description: The "Audit process tracking" parameter is used to log events that involve the opening and closing of processes. If enabled, this type of auditing creates a large number of entries in the log file. Because of that, it should be kept disabled in normal operating conditions.

criterion.comment: 'Audit process tracking' must be configured unchecking 'Success' and 'Failure'.

metadata.title: The "Audit system events" parameter should be set to "Success" and "Failure".
metadata.description: The "Audit system events" parameter is used to log events that involve system shutdown or restart. It is recommended that this type of auditing be enabled wherever possible, so as to help administrators collect information about system shutdowns and restarts, both intentional and inadvertent ones.

criterion.comment: 'Audit system events' must be configured as 'Success' and 'Failure'.

metadata.title: The "RunAs" parameter in the Registry should be removed from all subkeys under the "HKLM\Software\Classes\AppID" key.
metadata.description: The "RunAs" parameter determines the user credentials under whose context an application or service will run. All "RunAs" parameters should be removed to make applications and services run under the context of the user whom the system has authenticated at the time. This way, attackers will be prevented from running applications using administrative users' credentials.

criterion.comment: Check if there is any RunAs

metadata.title: The "Telnet" service should be disabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "Telnet" service is used to run applications and manage the system through a remote console. All network traffic of this service is not encrypted and may be intercepted by an attacker. Thus, an attacker can obtain user passwords among other things. For this reason, it is recommended that this service be disabled whenever possible.

criterion.comment: Check if Telnet service is disabled

metadata.title: The "NoDefaultExempt" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1" on the Windows XP system.
metadata.description: By default, even when the computer has been set to use IPSec for all inbound and outbound packets, some types of packets are sent and received without passing through the IPSec tunnel. These types are "Broadcast", Multicast", RSVP", "IKE" and "Kerberos". The "NoDefaultExempt" parameter determines which types of packets will not pass through the IPSec tunnel. It is recommended that this parameter be set to "1" so that only "Multicast", "Broadcast" and "IKE" packets are allowed to pass outside the IPSec tunnel. To secure these packets, filters should be applied to the ports they use.

criterion.comment: NoDefaultExempt exist?.
NoDefaultExempt must be 1.

metadata.title: The "WebView" parameter in the Registry should be set to "0".
metadata.description: The "WebView" parameter allows documents in a folder to be executed in preview mode. This means that the user only needs to select the document in order to open it in preview mode on the left side of the folder. It is recommended that this parameter be disabled to prevent HTML, DOC and other types of documents, which may contain malicious code, from being executed simply by having the file selected. This would not only jeopardize the integrity, confidentiality and availability of the documents, but also facilitate attacks using the aforementioned code against the system itself.

criterion.comment: Check if WebView is 0

metadata.title: The "NetMeeting Remote Desktop Sharing" service should be disabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "NetMeeting Remote Desktop Sharing" service is used for sharing the Windows desktop, so that a remote client can gain access to it. Therefore, an attacker can gain access to sensitive information. For this reason, it this recommended that this service be disabled whenever possible.

criterion.comment: NetMeeting Remote Desktop Sharing must be disabled.

metadata.title: The "Internet Information Services (IIS)" should be disabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: IIS (Internet Information Services) is used to host Internet sites. Some of the services included in this package are not necessary - depending on the environment in question - and may have security flaws that could lead to a loss of system availability, integrity and confidentiality. Thus, IIS (Internet Information Services) should be disabled or removed when not needed.

criterion.comment: Check if start parameter is disabled in ISSADMIN service
Check if ISSADMIN service key exists

metadata.title: The Windows XP DEP (Data Execution Prevention) feature should be enabled.
metadata.description: The DEP feature is used to avoid problems caused by programs that contain malicious code aimed at generating buffer overflows on the system. This is a kernel feature and is available only on systems where the Windows XP Service Pack 2 is installed. In cases where the computer has a 64-bit processor, DEP is also implemented at the hardware level.

criterion.comment: Shows what's in boot.ini .

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemDrive%\Documents and Settings\[administrator]" directory should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemDrive%\Documents and Settings\[administrator]" directory is used to store the system administrator profile. To prevent malicious users from accessing system administrator's files, it is recommended that NTFS permissions on this directory be set in a way that prevents unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect the permissions of the directory '%SystemDrive%\Documents and Settings\[administrator_user]' - Administrators and System: Full Control.

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\$NtUninstall[folder_name]" directory should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\$NtUninstall[folder_name]" directory stores files used to uninstall hot fixes and other applications. To prevent these files from being altered or removed, which would make it impossible to uninstall hot fixes and other applications, NTFS permissions on this directory should be set to block unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Permissions of '%SystemRoot%\$NtUninstall[folder_name]' - Administrators and System: Full Control.
Collect the permissions of C:\WINDOWS\$NtUninstall[folder_name] - SID's Verification

metadata.title: The "Application Layer Gateway Service" should be disabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "Application Layer Gateway Service" is a subcomponent of the "Internet Connection Share" ("ICS") and of the "Internet Connection Firewall" ("ICF") used to provide support for third-party program "plug-ins". Such "plug-ins" are able to open computer ports, among other functions. This service should be disabled wherever possible, to prevent attackers from gaining unauthorized access to the system by using these "plug-ins" to open security breaches.

criterion.comment: 'Application Layer Gateway Service' must be disabled

metadata.title: The "BlockSendInputResets" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "BlockSendInputResets" parameter determines whether the system will accept external interruptions that may prevent the screensaver from being executed. Attackers may use these interruptions for preventing the screensaver from being activated when a user carelessly leaves his computer unattended without having locked the system. For this reason, it is recommended that external interruptions be disabled on the system.

criterion.comment: 'BlockSendInputResets' must be enabled

metadata.title: The "Domain member: Digitally sign secure channel data (when possible)" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Domain member: Digitally sign secure channel data (when possible)" parameter determines whether the computer will, wherever possible, sign data packets passing through a secure channel. Data traffic in a secure channel is authenticated and sensitive information is encrypted. However, the integrity of the channel is not checked and not all information is encrypted. If this parameter is disabled, traffic will not be digitally signed.

criterion.comment: 'Domain member: Digitally sign secure channel data (when possible)' must be enabled

metadata.title: The maximum size for the audit files of Windows XP and the "Active Directory" service should be specified.
metadata.description: By properly specifying the maximum size of the audit files used by Windows XP and the "Active Directory" service, the risk of unnecessarily using up disk space is reduced. If a maximum size for these files is not determined, available disk space could become so reduced that it would no longer be possible to write to the audit files. Traceability would be lost and the system could become unavailable due to a lack of sufficient disk space. For this reason, a maximum size for these files should be set.

criterion.comment: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Eventlog\System collect the value of 'MaxSize'.
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Eventlog\Application collect the value of 'MaxSize'.
HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Eventlog\Security collect the value of 'MaxSize'.

metadata.title: Windows XP should be configured to save a log whenever a fatal error occurs.
metadata.description: Implementation of this control ensures that a security log will be saved in order to document that the system has been restarted for technical reasons. This will allow the system Administrator to become aware of the issue, and research the causes for the fatal error (e.g. unexpected software and hardware failure).

criterion.comment: Save log if fatal error occurs

metadata.title: The "Remote Registry Service" should be disabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "Remote Registry Service" is used to make remote changes to the Registry. Attackers may use this functionality to gain access to the Registry and, thus, make changes to it in order to gain unauthorized access or make the system unavailable. For this reason, it is recommended that this service be disabled.

criterion.comment: Remote Registry Service must be disabled.

metadata.title: The Windows XP SNMP agent should be set up to send "traps" only to the authorized management hosts.
metadata.description: To avoid sending information about the status of agents and other alerts (for instance, password violations) to unauthorized hosts, SNMP "traps" should be sent only to those specific hosts where the computer's management is taking place.

criterion.comment: Send traps

metadata.title: The "PerformRouterDiscovery" Registry parameter should be set as follows: "0"
metadata.description: By default the IRDP protocol ("ICMP Router Discovery Protocol") is enabled for Windows clients using DHCP. This may represent a security threat because "IRPD Router Advertisements" messages can be forged in such a way that an attacker may remotely add route entries to remote systems, which will allow traffic to be redirected to an unreliable host.

criterion.comment: Show all interfaces

metadata.title: The "Simple TCP/IP Services" should disabled on the Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "Simple TCP/IP Services" installs the services "Character Generator" ("chargen"), "Daytime", "Discard", "Echo" and "Quote of the Day" in the system. These services present several security flaws that may be easily exploited by attackers. For this reason, it is recommended that the "Simple TCP/IP Services" be either disabled or removed.

criterion.comment: 'Simple TCP/IP' feature must be removed.

metadata.title: Access to Windows XP shared resources should be restricted to authorized users only.
metadata.description: By default, the access permissions granted by Windows when a resource is shared include the read access right for every user. Thus, it is recommended that these permissions be modified to make sure only authorized users will have access to the information. Accordingly, a user and group access control should be implemented for shares. It is also recommended that resources be shared through the network only when absolutely necessary.

criterion.comment: Show sharing paths, and the respective permissions

metadata.title: The name of the SNMP read-only community in the SNMP agent of Windows XP should be difficult to guess.
metadata.description: In practice, the community name works as a password protecting the communication between SNMP agents and managers. The name of the SNMP read only community should be difficult to guess, and the default name "PUBLIC" should not be used. This way, attackers will be prevented from remotely viewing information about the configuration of the agent.

criterion.comment: SNMP Community's name must be difficult to deduct.

metadata.title: The name of the SNMP read-write community in the SNMP agent of Windows XP should be difficult to guess.
metadata.description: In practice, the community name works as a password protecting the communication between SNMP agents and managers. The name of the SNMP "read-write" community should be difficult to guess; hence, the default name "PRIVATE" should not be used. This way, attackers will be prevented from remotely modifying the configuration settings of the agent via SNMP.

criterion.comment: SNMP Community's name must be difficult to deduct.

metadata.title: Read-write access to the Windows XP SNMP agent should be removed.
metadata.description: The read-write access permission on agents monitored via SNMP, such as servers, workstations, routers, switches, hubs, firewalls, access points and other devices on IP networks, allows their configuration settings to be modified remotely. Write access permission should be granted only when absolutely necessary. The name of the read-write community should be difficult to guess. Additionally, as SNMP messages are based on UDP and are transmitted in cleartext across the network, it is recommended that, wherever possible, the management traffic be isolated, for instance, by implementing a "VLAN".

criterion.comment: Check if SNMP registry exists.
Remove read-write SNMP Communities.

metadata.title: The Windows XP SNMP agent should be set up in such a way as to only accept SNMP packets from authorized computers.
metadata.description: It is recommended that only trusted computers be allowed to send SNMP packets to the agent. This prevents attackers from being able to use other computers to send forged SNMP packets to the agent, thereby obtaining unauthorized access or disrupting the agent's services.

criterion.comment: Accept SNMP packets from?

metadata.title: The "Terminal Services" should be disabled on Windows XP systems.
metadata.description: The "Terminal Services" are used to manage servers remotely. These services provide clients with a session whereby the client has access to the desktop of a remote computer, and can make the same changes the user would be able to make locally. These services should be disabled, whenever possible, to prevent attackers from using them to gain unauthorized access to the computer.

criterion.comment: 'Terminal Services' should be disabled.

metadata.title: The Windows XP installation folder as well as its subfolders should be audited.
metadata.description: Auditing of the Operating System's folder and subfolders allows the administrator to have greater control over access and activities carried out within these folders. In case there is any unauthorized or suspicious activity (e.g., modification or removal of system files), appropriate action may be undertaken by identifying the user who performed the activity.

criterion.comment: SystemRoot should be audited.

metadata.title: Windows XP should be configured to automatically restart after a fatal error.
metadata.description: In case the system has not been configured to automatically restart whenever an error that forces it to shut down occurs, its services and applications will become unavailable until it can be manually turned back on.

criterion.comment: Restart after fatal error.

metadata.title: The feature that creates memory dump files should be disabled.
metadata.description: Creating memory dump files can be useful for investigating machine crashes, for instance, when a "Stop Error" causing a BSOD (Blue Screen of Death) occurs. However, these files may contain confidential data that were stored in memory at the time, such as access passwords to applications. In environments that require high security, it is recommended that the creation of Dump Files be disabled whenever possible.

criterion.comment: 'DUMP' should be disabled.

metadata.title: The "Domain member: Maximum machine account password age" parameter should be set to a value ranging from "10" and "30".
metadata.description: The "Domain member: Maximum machine account password age" parameter determines the maximum time before a machine account password expires. By default, members of the domain have their passwords automatically changed every 30 days. Increasing too much this period, or reducing it to "0" (what makes changing the password non-obligatory), means that attackers will have more time to try to crack the password using dictionary of brute force techniques. An interval of 10 to 30 days between password changes is adequate for most implementations.

criterion.comment: 'Domain member: Maximum machine account password age' must be between 10 and 30

metadata.title: The "Domain member: Disable machine account password changes" parameter should be set to "Disabled" or "Not defined".
metadata.description: The "Domain member: Disable machine account password changes" parameter determines whether member users of the domain will be able to change the machine's account password registered with the domain. In case this parameter is enabled, attackers will be able to change the machine's account password and gain access to sensitive information being transmitted, even if protected by a Windows secure communication channel.

criterion.comment: 'Domain member: Disable machine account password changes' must be disabled

metadata.title: The "PipeFirewallActive" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "PipeFirewallActive" parameter determines whether the system will filter access to the named pipes. Once enabled, this filter will not allow access to named pipes that are not present in the "AllowedPipes" parameter in the Registry. It is recommended that this parameter be enabled in order to prevent attackers from gaining unauthorized access to system resources through named pipes.

criterion.comment: PipeFirewallActive must equal to 1.

metadata.title: The auditing of activities on the system drive (indicated by the "%SystemDrive%" variable) should be set to log security relevant events.
metadata.description: The "%SystemDrive%" disk drive is the hard disk where the operating system is installed. Every access to this drive should be logged in order to have greater control over both the access to, and the activities that affect the directories and files stored on the drive. If any unauthorized or suspicious activity (for instance, modification or removal of system files) occurs, appropriate action can be taken, such as identifying the user who carried out the activity.

criterion.comment: Check if file's auditing is full control failed

metadata.title: Access to the "HKLM\Software" Registry key should be audited.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\Software" Registry key is used to store configuration information of the software that has been installed on the computer. Every access to this key should be logged in order to have greater control over both the access to and the activities that affect the key. If any unauthorized or suspicious activity (for instance, modification or removal of system files) occurs, appropriate action can be taken, such as identifying the user who carried out the activity.

criterion.comment: Check if registry's auditing is full control failed

metadata.title: Access to the "HKLM\System" Registry key should be audited.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\System" Registry key is used to store information regarding the configuration of the system. Every access to this key should be logged in order to have greater control over both the access to and the activities that affect the key. If any unauthorized or suspicious activity (for instance, modification or removal of system files) occurs, appropriate action can be taken, such as identifying the user who carried out the activity.

criterion.comment: Check if registry's auditing is full control failed

metadata.title: The "DisableSavePassword" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "DisableSavePassword" parameter determines whether the operating system will enable the option to store the user's dial-up connection authentication credentials. When stored by the system, it is no longer necessary to key in these credentials when a connection request is made. It is recommended that this parameter be set up in a way as to not allow a user's credentials to be stored in the system. This way, attackers will not be able to gain access to other computers through a user's dial-up connection.

criterion.comment: Default must be configured as regedit.exe %1

metadata.title: The association of "*.reg" files with the "regedit.exe" program should be removed.
metadata.description: By default, Windows associates "*.reg" files with the "regedit.exe" program (the Registry editor). It is recommended that the association of this type of file with "regedit.exe" be removed and, instead, be associated with "notepad.exe" or any other text editor. This way, malicious users will not be able to run files with this extension and modify Registry information.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
MaxPacketSize must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "OperationMode" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "OperationMode" parameter determines whether traffic sent or received by the computer will be blocked if the "IPSec" agents have not yet been loaded. It is recommended that any traffic, incoming or outgoing, be blocked until IPSec agents are able to properly deal with this traffic. This helps prevent forged packets from being received or sent during attempts to access the system.

criterion.comment: OperationMode must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "IP Forwarding" resource should be disabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "IPEnableRouter" parameter determines whether the "IP Forwarding" feature will be enabled on the system or not. It is recommended that the system's "IP Forwarding" feature be disabled wherever possible. If this parameter is enabled, malicious users would be able to use Windows XP on systems with more than one network interface to route packets without permission, as well as to launch "ARP Spoofing" attacks.

criterion.comment: IP Forwarding must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "UPnPMode" parameter in the Registry should be set to a value of "2".
metadata.description: The "UPnPMode" parameter determines whether SSDP ("Simple Service Discovery Protocol") will be used to locate the Plug and Play devices in the network. Even when this service is disabled, an incorrect configuration of this parameter in the Registry may allow Windows Messenger to send messages in search of these devices on the network.

criterion.comment: UPnPMode must be configured as 2

metadata.title: The Windows XP "Restrictions for Unauthenticated RPC clients" parameter should be enabled.
metadata.description: The "Restrictions for Unauthenticated RPC clients" parameter determines whether RPC clients are able to connect to computers that are functioning as RPC servers without needing to be authenticated. In this way, attackers can obtain unauthorized logical access to the system and the system loses traceability, as all the unauthorized connections are anonymous.

criterion.comment: RestrictRemClient must be configured as 2

metadata.title: The "Recovery console: Allow floppy copy and access to all drives and all folders" parameter should be set to "Disabled".

criterion.comment: RCSet must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Devices: Prevent users from installing printer drivers" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Devices: Prevent users from installing printer drivers" parameter prevents normal users from being able to install print "drivers" on the system, which run in privileged mode as part of the Kernel. If a corrupted "driver" containing some malicious code, or which is not compatible with Windows, is installed, errors may occur that affect the integrity of the system, possibly rendering it unavailable and thus requiring recovery. As good security practice, the installation of "drivers" should be restricted to administrators.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
SAddPrintDrivers must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Interactive logon: Smart card removal behavior" parameter should be set to "Lock workstation" or "Force logoff".
metadata.description: The "Interactive logon: Smart card removal behavior" parameter determines how the system will behave when a smart card device is removed from the reader. Smart cards are programmable devices that can be used for end user authentication into Windows. They can contain digital certificates and associated keys. It is good security practice to set up the workstation so that it will either be locked or the user session terminated when the smart card is removed from the reader. This way, it will only be possible to use the system while the smart card remains inserted.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
ScRemove must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Microsoft network client: Send unencrypted password to third-party SMB servers" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: When the "Microsoft network client: Send unencrypted password to third-party SMB servers" parameter is enabled, the "Server Message Block (SMB) Redirector" service transmits plaintext passwords across the network to non-Microsoft third-party SMB servers that do not support encrypted passwords during authentication. This facilitates the capture of passwords as they travel across the network, thereby allowing unauthorized access to the systems. For this reason, this parameter should remain disabled wherever possible.

criterion.comment: EnablePlainTextPassword must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Shutdown: Allow system to be shut down without having to log on" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Shutdown: Allow system to be shut down without having to log on" parameter determines whether the computer can be shut down by someone who has not yet been authenticated into the system. It is recommended that the right to shut down the system be restricted to administrator users only. Therefore, the system should require a "logon" in order to identify the user.

criterion.comment: ShutdownWithoutLogon must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Microsoft network server: Amount of idle time required before suspending session" parameter should be set to a value of "15".
metadata.description: The "Microsoft network server: Amount of idle time required before suspending session" parameter determines the amount of idle time that should pass during a SMB ("Server Message Block") session before it is suspended. Maintaining inactive connections for long periods uses resources and increases the opportunity for certain types of attacks against the system. For generic environments, this parameter should be set to a value of "15".

criterion.comment: AutoDisconnect must be configured as 15

metadata.title: The "Audit: Audit the access of global system objects" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Audit: Audit the access of global system objects" parameter enables the auditing of access to global system objects. When enabled, "semaphores" and "DOS Devices" system objects will be created with a default "System Access Control List" (SACL). When the "object access" audit policy is enabled, access to these objects will be audited. This type of auditing creates a large number of security log entries. It is only recommended for environments where a very rigorous audit is necessary. A policy for log file maintenance and configuration of storage attributes should be put in place.

criterion.comment: AuditBaseObjects must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Audit: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Audit: Audit the use of Backup and Restore privilege" parameter determines whether an event will be generated whenever the "Backup files and directories" or "Restore files and directories" user rights are used. Usually, the use of these rights is not audited. This type of auditing creates a large number of security log entries. It is only recommended for environments where a very rigorous audit is necessary. A policy for log file maintenance and configuration of storage attributes should be put in place.

criterion.comment: FullPrivilegeAuditing must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Network security: LAN Manager authentication level" parameter should be set to "Send NTLMv2 response only. Refuse LM and NTLM".
metadata.description: The "Network security: LAN Manager authentication level" parameter configures the authentication method used by the Windows Challenge/Response mechanism, in order to determine the level of protection used when logons are performed across the network. The "LM" protocol allows passwords in plaintext, which makes it less secure in comparison with the "NTLM" protocol. However, there are security flaws in the "NTLM" protocol that allow passwords to be cracked. To correct these flaws, Microsoft released version 2 of the NTLM protocol, which contains additional security features such as: the use of a unique session key per connection; session key establishment protected by Key Exchange; the generation of unique keys for encryption and for ensuring session data integrity.

criterion.comment: LmCompatibilityLevel must be configured as 5

metadata.title: The "ScreenSaverGracePeriod" parameter in the Registry should be set to "0".
metadata.description: The "ScreenSaverGracePeriod" parameter determines how long it will take for the computer to be blocked after the Screen Saver starts running. In the standard installation, when the Screen Saver starts running, the computer is not immediately blocked. It is recommended that the system be blocked immediately in a way that would prevent attackers from obtaining access to the computer by taking advantage of the careless behavior of a user.

criterion.comment: ScreenSaverGracePeriod must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available)" parameter should be set to "0".
metadata.description: The "Interactive logon: Number of previous logons to cache (in case domain controller is not available)" parameter specifies the number of user account credentials that will be stored in the cache. Windows can cache logon information. When the Domain Controller is not available during the logon process and the user has previously logged on to the system, Windows can use these credentials to authenticate the user again. When the parameter is set to "0", Windows will not store any information. In this case, if the Domain Controller is not available when the user attempts to log on, the logon will not proceed. On the other hand, with the cache enabled, even if the Administrator disables the user account, the user will still be able to log on by disconnecting the network cable. To avoid this type of security breach, the cache should be disabled wherever possible, even though this will require a lengthier "logon" process.

criterion.comment: CachedLogonsCount must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Interactive logon: Prompt user to change password before expiration" parameter should be set to "14".
metadata.description: The "Interactive logon: Prompt user to change password before expiration" parameter specifies how many days before the expiration date that Windows XP will start prompting a user to change his password. This value should allow the user sufficient time to compose a high quality password in accordance with the security policy. 14 (days) represents sufficient time for the majority of organizations.

criterion.comment: PasswordExpiryWarning must be configured as 14

metadata.title: The "Recovery Console: Allow automatic administrative logon" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Recovery Console: Allow automatic administrative logon" parameter, once enabled, determines that the system, when entering the "Recovery Console" mode, will automatically use the logon credentials of the administrator user. As a result, various changes can be made to the system that could lead to security breaches, such as the removal or modification of files, among other changes. For this reason, this parameter should be disabled.

criterion.comment: RCAdmin must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Devices: Restrict CD-ROM access to locally logged-on user only" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Devices: Restrict CD-ROM access to locally logged-on user only" parameter determines whether only the locally logged-on user has access to the CD-ROM drives or if these drives can be accessed simultaneously over the network. If the parameter is disabled and no one is logged-on locally, any user with access permissions to the CD-ROM drive will be able to access it over the network. To prevent a drop in performance and to stop remote users from gaining unauthorized access to information stored on CD-ROMs, this parameter should be enabled.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
AllocateCDRoms must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Devices: Restrict floppy access to locally logged-on user only" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Devices: Restrict floppy access to locally logged-on user only" parameter determines whether only the locally logged-on user has access to the floppy disk drives or if these drives can be accessed simultaneously over the network. If the parameter is disabled and no one is logged-on locally, any user with access permissions to the floppy disk drives will be able to access them over the network. To prevent a drop in performance and to stop remote users from gaining unauthorized access to information stored on floppy disks, this parameter should be enabled.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
AllocateFloppies must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Audit: Shut down system immediately if unable to log security audits" parameter determines whether the system will be switched off when it is not possible to write security-related events to the Security Log. It is recommended that this option be disabled wherever possible. Otherwise, attackers could make the system generate a sufficiently large number of security log entries to cause its unavailability in a denial-of-service attack.

criterion.comment: CrashOnAuditFail must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Turn off Windows Update device driver searching" parameter on Windows XP should be disabled.
metadata.description: The "Turn off Windows Update device driver searching" parameter determines whether or not Windows will search device drivers using Windows Update. Upon installing a new device, Windows may or may not query the Windows Update driver database before installing another driver. It is recommended to disable this parameter as the drivers made available by Microsoft have been tested and signed, which ensures their compatibility with the Operating System. Additionally, attackers may include malicious code within drivers so as to infect computers attempting to install the driver in question.

criterion.comment: DriveSearching must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Interactive logon: Do not require CTRL+ALT+DEL" parameter should not be enabled under normal circumstances. Enabling this parameter will allow logon session spoofing. Therefore, malicious users may install an application that simulates the logon process in order to collect usernames and passwords.

criterion.comment: DisableCAD must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Interactive logon: Do not display last user name" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Interactive logon: Do not display last user name" parameter establishes whether or not the username belonging to the last user to log onto the system will be displayed in the logon window when a new user attempts to log on. As good security practice, it is recommended to enable this parameter in order to prevent attackers from obtaining usernames displayed in the logon window.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
DontDisplayLastUserName must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Domain member: Digitally encrypt secure channel data (when possible)" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Domain member: Digitally encrypt secure channel data (when possible)" parameter determines whether or not the computer will digitally encrypt sensitive data exchanged between domain workstations and servers. In order to ensure information confidentiality and integrity, it is recommended to enable this parameter whenever possible (default).

criterion.comment: 'Domain member: Digitally encrypt secure channel data (when possible)' must be enabled

metadata.title: Screen-saving methods should be implemented in case the Windows XP operator leaves the server unattended.
metadata.description: Locking the computer is an important protection against unauthorized access. In case malicious users gain physical access to an unattended computer, they may access sensitive information and alter settings in the context of the user account currently authenticated (possibly the system Administrator). In order to avoid problems, it is recommended that the Administrator be instructed to lock the computer whenever it is left unattended. Moreover, the system should be set up so as to display a password-protected screensaver after it has been inactive for a certain amount of time.

criterion.comment: ScreenSaveActiveDefault must be configured as 1
ScreenSaverIsSecure must be configured as 1
ScreenSaveTimeout must be configured as 180
DisableCAD must be configured as 0

metadata.title: Only administrators should be allowed to configure Windows XP Print services.
metadata.description: The "Printer Spooler", "Printer Availability", "Printer Priority" and "Scheduling" parameters, among others, are used for setting up the memory reserved for the printing process, the time of day in which printing is allowed, priorities for queues on the same printer, and printing schedules. Since these parameters affect the configuration of the Print services for all users, only administrators should be allowed to set them up.

criterion.comment: Show printers and permissions

metadata.title: The "IP Source Routing" resource should be disabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: "Source Routing" is a resource that allows an "origin host" to specify the exact route that IP packages should follow until reaching the "target host", including a list with the routers that should process the package in the "Options" field of IP datagrams. The resource was initially implemented to allow IP packages to be routed in a controlled manner (by specific routers), avoiding congested connections, defective links, etc. In practice, this resource is rarely used nowadays. If the "Source Routing" resource is enabled, it may be used for attacks in which the attacker can forge packages using an IP address of any reliable origin and the replies of these packages will be sent to his address and not to the actual origin host's address. Therefore, the resources and information available to the reliable host also become available to the attacker. For security reasons it is recommended to disable the "Source Routing" parameter whenever possible.

criterion.comment: DisableIPSourceRouting must be configured as 2

metadata.title: "ICMP Redirect" packets should be blocked on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "EnableICMPRedirect" parameter defines whether the computer routes table will be altered every time it receives "ICMP Redirect" packages. It is advisable that this parameter be set up so as not to change the routes table when "ICMP Redirect" packages are received, given that attackers may send this type of package in order to alter the routes table inadequately and, thus, compromise the security system.

criterion.comment: EnableICMPRedirect must be configured as 0

metadata.title: Protection against "Syn-Flood" attacks should be enabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The purpose of "Syn Flood" attacks is to make TCP/IP based services unavailable by exploiting the TCP/IP connection set-up process ("3-way-handshake"). Through continuous connection requests, which are never completed, it is possible to drain system resources, rendering its services unavailable. For security reasons it is recommended to enable the resource which protects the system against "Syn Flood" attacks.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
SynAttackProtect must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "EnableDeadGWDetect" Registry parameter should be set as follows: "0"
metadata.description: When the "EnableDeadGWDetect" parameter is set to 1 ("default"), the TCP protocol may make a "dead-gateway" detection and then use the Internet Protocol (IP) to redirect the route to a "backup gateway" in case any connections are experiencing difficulties This resource may be used in attacks which cause the "backup gateway" address to be changed and packages to be sent to an undesired route. In order to prevent these attacks, it is recommended that the "EnableDeadGWDetect" parameter be set to 0 whenever possible.

criterion.comment: EnableDeadGWDetect must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communication (if client agrees)" parameter should be set as follows: "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communication (if client agrees)" parameter should be enabled so the system may use, whenever possible, the "SMB Signing" resource which assures the integrity of SMB protocol messages. Note that this implementation may degrade system performance (by an estimated 10%).

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
EnableSMBSignServer must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Microsoft network server: Disconnect clients when logon hours expire" parameter should be set as follows: "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Microsoft network server: Disconnect clients when logon hours expire" parameter defines whether a user with expired logon time will be made to log off. It is advisable to set this parameter to "Enabled" so as to prevent users from utilizing the computer beyond the allowed time.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
EnableForcedLogoff must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Shutdown: Clear virtual memory pagefile" parameter should be set as follows: "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Shutdown: Clear virtual memory pagefile" parameter defines whether the virtual memory pagefile will be removed whenever the computer is shut down. This is done in order to prevent sensitive information contained in the paging file from becoming available to other users. There will be performance degradation during the shutdown process due to the removal of the paging.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
ClearPageFileAtShutdown must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (always)" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Microsoft network client: Digitally sign communications (always)" parameter defines whether the system will always be forced to use the "SMB Signing" resource, which supports mutual authentication and ensures the integrity of SMB protocol messages. It also prevents "man-in-the-middle" attacks. It is recommended that this resource be enabled whenever possible.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
RequireSMBSignRDR must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Microsoft Network client: Digitally sign communications (if Server agrees)" parameter should be set as follows: "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Microsoft Network client: Digitally sign communications (if Server agrees)" parameter should be enabled so the system may use, whenever possible, the "SMB Signing" resource which assures the integrity of SMB protocol messages. Note that this implementation may degrade system performance (by an estimated 10%).

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
EnableSMBSignRDR must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Devices: Allowed to format and eject removable media" parameter should be set as follows: "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Devices: Allowed to format and eject removable media" parameter defines which user accounts are allowed to format and eject NTFS media present in the system. Uncontrolled ejection and formatting of removable media by unauthorized users may jeopardize access control settings and, thus, lead to the loss of information confidentiality, integrity and availability.

criterion.comment: AllocateDASD must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (always)" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Microsoft network server: Digitally sign communications (always)" parameter defines whether the system will always be forced to use the "SMB Signing" resource, which ensures the integrity of SMB protocol messages in the communication between domain servers. This setting should only be enabled to ensure the integrity of SMB packets.

criterion.comment: RequireSMBSignServer must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "WarningLevel" parameter in the Registry should be set to "90".
metadata.description: The "WarningLevel" parameter is used to specify a percentage of the maximum log size that, when reached, will make the system write an entry into the security log. It is recommended that, for generic environments, this parameter be set to "90", meaning "90%" of the maximum audit log size.

criterion.comment: WarningLevel must be configured as 90

metadata.title: The "TcpMaxConnectRetransmissions" parameter in the Registry should be set to "3" on the Windows XP system.
metadata.description: The "TcpMaxConnectRetransmissions" parameter determines how many times a TCP packet can be retransmitted if a request for a new connection is not answered.TCP retransmits requests for new connections until it gets a response or until the number of attempts defined in this parameter is reached. A large amount of retransmissions, besides increasing the network traffic, may lead to a decrease in performance of the system or even to its unavailability. For this reason, it is recommended that, for generic environments, this parameter be set to "3" retransmissions.

criterion.comment: TcpMaxConnectRetransmissions must be configured as 3

metadata.title: The "TCPMaxConnectResponseRetransmissions" Registry parameter should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "TcpMaxConnectResponseRetransmissions" parameter is used to re-transmit a SYN-ACK after a certain amount of time. By default, this parameter is set to "2", which will discard connections after 21 seconds. However, in order to minimize the likelihood of successful Syn-Flood attacks, which can render the system unavailable, it is recommended that this parameter be set to "1", which will discard connections after 9 seconds.

criterion.comment: TcpMaxConnectResponseRetransmissions must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "Network Access: Shares that can be accessed anonymously" parameter should be set in such a way as to allow anonymous users to access authorized shares only.
metadata.description: The "Network Access: Shares that can be accessed anonymously" parameter is used to identify which shares anonymous users will be able to access. Wherever possible, anonymous user access to shares should be disabled or restricted to authorized shares only, in a way that enhances traceability and reduces the risk of unauthorized access to shared resources.

criterion.comment: Show Network Access: Shares that can be accessed anonymously

metadata.title: The "Network Access: Sharing and security model for local accounts" parameter should be set to "Classic: local users authenticate as themselves".
metadata.description: The "Network Access: Sharing and security model for local accounts" parameter determines how the local accounts will be authenticated. It is recommended that this parameter be set to "Classic: local users authenticated as themselves" so as to guarantee better control of which users are being authenticated, for the other authentication method allows only the Guest user to authenticate himself to the system.

criterion.comment: forceguest must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Network security: Do not store LAN Manager hash value on next password change" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Network security: Do not store LAN Manager hash value on next password change" parameter determines whether the operating system will store LM ("Lan Manager") hashes of user account passwords. Windows generates and stores user passwords using two types of hashes, the LM hash and the NT Hash. They are stored either locally in the SAM ("Security Account Manager") file or in the domain controller's database if the client-computer is part of the domain. LM hashes should not be stored since they are considered weak and can be easily cracked by means of brute force attacks, thus increasing the risk of user passwords being viewed by unauthorized persons.

criterion.comment: Reg_nolmhash must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "System cryptography: Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing and signing" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "System cryptography: Use FIPS compliant algorithms for encryption, hashing and signing" parameter forces the system to use strong encryption algorithms. FIPS compliant algorithms comply with a standard established by the United States government. FIPS compliant algorithms should be used for encryption, hashing and signing to protect the integrity and confidentiality of sensitive information.

criterion.comment: fipsalgorithmpolicy must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "Accounts: Limit local account use of blank passwords to console logon only" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Accounts: Limit local account use of blank passwords to console logon only" parameter is used to determine whether local user accounts which have not been associated with a password will be allowed to remotely access the system using FTP, Terminal Services, or other services. If this were allowed, attackers would be able to use these accounts to access the system without permission. Therefore, it is recommended that this parameter be enabled in order to block this type of access.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
limitblankpassworduse must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "NtfsDisable8dot3NameCreation" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "NtfsDisable8dot3NameCreation" determines whether the system will create files using the "NTFS 8.3" format. By default, Windows generates file names compatible with MS-DOS applications in all NTFS volumes for compatibility with 16 bits programs. It is recommended that this feature be disabled, thus improving system performance.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
NtfsDisable8dot3NameCreation must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "SafeDllSearchMode" Registry parameter should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "SafeDllSearchMode" parameter defines how Windows searches for program DLLs when that program is executed. Windows has two types of DLL searches. The first looks for DLLs in the directory where the program was executed and later in the directory informed by the system path, whereas the second type searches first in directories appearing in the system path and then in the directory where the program was executed. It is recommended that the system use the second search method, as attackers can send files with malicious code which, when decompressed, may contain modified DLLs and thus compromise the system.

criterion.comment: SafeDllSearchMode must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "Devices: Allow undock without having to log on" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Devices: Allow undock without having to log on" parameter allows computers to which no user is authenticated to be disconnected from their docking stations. This option should be disabled so as to prevent unauthorized users from removing the computer from the docking station and making the operating system mal-function. When improperly disconnected, the computer may be forced to interrupt services and even become unavailable due to operating system failures.

criterion.comment: undockwithoutlogon must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "NoDriveTypeAutoRun" parameter in the Registry should be set to "255".
metadata.description: The "NoDriveTypeAutoRun" parameter determines whether programs will run automatically when the storage medium on which they are recorded is inserted in any of the computer's drives. It is recommended that the "AutoRun" feature be disabled to prevent malicious code from being automatically executed. Attackers may insert malicious code into programs that use the "AutoRun" feature to have the code automatically run on the system, compromising its security.

criterion.comment: NoDriveTypeAutoRun must be configured as 255

metadata.title: The "Network Access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Network Access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts" parameter determines whether the system will allow the domain user accounts, present in the computer's local SAM, to be listed. Once in possession of this information, attackers will be able to find the administrator and other sensitive accounts within the system. Thus, it will be possible to apply brute force and dictionary techniques in an attempt to crack their passwords.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
restrictanonymoussam must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Address Mask Request" package response resource should be disabled on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "EnableAddrMaskReply" parameter is used to return the sub-net mask through requests using type 17 ICMP packages. Attackers can send this type of package to network computers so as to map the network and, thus, obtain information for future attacks.

criterion.comment: EnableAddrMaskReply must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Network access: Do not allow storage of credentials or .NET Passports for network authentication" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Network access: Do not allow storage of credentials or .NET Passports for network authentication" parameter specifies whether the system will store credentials or ".NET Passports" using the "Credential Manager". The "Credential Manager" stores this information and uses it when a network connection is established, making the authentication transparent to the user. It is recommended that this parameter be enabled in order to prevent attackers from obtaining access to this information.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
disabledomaincreds must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "Network Access: Let Everyone permissions apply to anonymous users" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Network Access: Let Everyone permissions apply to anonymous users" parameter is used to determine if anonymous users will have the same privileges as set up for the "Everyone" group. If this parameter is enabled, any anonymous user will also be able to list network users and groups. Therefore, this parameter should be disabled in order to prevent attackers from obtaining anonymous access to the system and thereby being able to use the "Everyone" group privileges to open security breaches for future attacks.

criterion.comment: everyoneincludesanonymous must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "TcpMaxDataRetransmissions" Registry parameter should be set to "3" on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "TcpMaxDataRetransmissions" parameter defines how many times the TCP protocol will retransmit an individual data segment before aborting the connection. It is recommended that this parameter be set to "3" so as to retransmit the segment three times.

criterion.comment: TcpMaxDataRetransmissions must be configured as 3

metadata.title: The "Network Access: Named Pipes that can be accessed anonymously" parameter should be set up to only allow anonymous access to the "Named Pipes" that have been specified.
metadata.description: The "Network Access: Named Pipes that can be accessed anonymously" parameter specifies which "named pipes" can be accessed by anonymous users. "Named Pipes" are internal communication processes identified by an ID number which varies according to the system. Specifying which "named pipes" can be accessed by anonymous users is recommended, to prevent these processes from being used by attackers who intend to compromise the system or gain unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Show Network Access: Named Pipes that can be accessed anonymously

metadata.title: The "Network Access: Remotely accessible registry paths" parameter should be set up to prevent unauthorized access by anonymous users.
metadata.description: The "Network Access: Remotely accessible registry paths" parameter specifies which Registry paths can be accessed by anonymous users. Registry paths to which anonymous access is undesirable should be removed from this parameter. Attackers with access to the system Registry can cause some services or even the system itself to become unavailable, and obtain unauthorized access to it. As the user will be anonymous, there will be loss of traceability.

criterion.comment: Show Network Access: Remotely accessible registry paths

metadata.title: The "Network security: LDAP client signing requirements" parameter should be set to "Negotiate signing".
metadata.description: The "Network security: LDAP client signing requirements" parameter allows the use of digital signatures in communications between clients and LDAP servers. If the server accepts the signature, the client will be notified and will start transmitting information with a digital signature. In cases where "TLS/SSL" is used, the signature request is not made by the client. This parameter should be set up so that the client and server are made to negotiate the use of digital signatures in their communications. The use of a digital signature prevents the loss of integrity of the information transmitted between clients and servers, as well as the compromise of user passwords, which could lead to unauthorized logical access to the system.

criterion.comment: ldapclientintegrity must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire" parameter determines whether the system will forcibly disconnect client users who have gone over their time limit on the server. This parameter should be enabled in order to prevent connections to the server from being established outside the times permitted by the Security Policy of the organization.

criterion.comment: The parameter Network security: Force logoff when logon hours expire must be configured as Enabled.

metadata.title: The "System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "System objects: Require case insensitivity for non-Windows subsystems" parameter determines whether Windows subsystems will require case insensitivity, not differentiating between upper and lower case characters, as does the win32 subsystem. In case this parameter is disabled, an attacker may manipulate the system to create new files with the same filenames of existing ones and, thus, lead the user to access fake files.

criterion.comment: ObCaseInsensitive must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "Interactive logon: Require smart card" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Interactive logon: Require smart card" parameter determines whether smart cards will be required for authentication into the system. A smart card is a programmable device that can be used for end user authentication into Windows. It can contain digital certificates and associated keys. When enabled, this parameter determines that users will be required to authenticate themselves into the system by means of a smart card. It is recommended that smart cards be used in order to enhance the security of the user authentication process on the server.

criterion.comment: ScForceOption must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Network access: Do not allow anonymous enumeration of SAM accounts and shares" parameter determines whether anonymous users will be able both to list the names of domain accounts stored in the system's SAM ("Security Accounts Manager") and to list the shares in the system. By default, Windows allows anonymous users to have this type of privilege, so that system administrators can grant access to users in a trusted domain that does not maintain a reciprocal trust. However, this could become a security breach allowing attackers to list valid domain accounts for future brute force or dictionary attacks.

criterion.comment: RestrictAnonymous must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The execution of Windows Messenger on Windows XP should be avoided.
metadata.description: Windows Messenger is a program used for the real-time exchange of messages and files. It is recommended not to allow the software to be run so as to avoid receiving files containing viruses or Trojans.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
PreventRunInMSn must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "EnableSecurityFilters" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1" on the Windows XP system.
metadata.description: The "EnableSecurityFilters" parameter determines whether the UDP, IP and TCP-SYN packet filtering is activated. It is recommended that these filters be activated in order to prevent attackers from sending forged packets of these specific types and, consequently, from breaching system security. This would jeopardize the confidentiality, availability and integrity of information stored on the system.

criterion.comment: EnableSecurityFilters must be configured as 1

metadata.title: Windows XP's DNS Spoofing protection should be enabled.
metadata.description: The "QueryipMatching" parameter determines whether the computer, when querying a DNS server, will accept information only from the DNS server that has received its request. It is recommended that the client computer must only accept information from the DNS server that has received its original request. This prevents attackers from sending wrong information to the client computer through a malicious DNS server.

criterion.comment: QueryipMatching must be configured as 1

metadata.title: Windows XP's "Do not process the legacy list" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Do not process the legacy list" parameter determines whether programs included in the Registry's "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" key will run. This parameter stores the paths to the executables that will run immediately after the operating system has been loaded. It is recommended not to run programs indicated by this parameter. This way, attackers will be prevented from including in it malicious programs that would be executed every time the computer is started.

criterion.comment: DisableLocalMachineRun must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The Windows XP DEP (Data Execution Prevention) resource should be set up to check all programs executed on the computer..
metadata.description: By default, the DEP resource only checks Operating System files. Therefore, other programs are not checked by this resource when executed, which renders the system susceptible to Buffer-Overflow attacks. It is recommended to configure this resource so that it checks all programs executed on the computer.

criterion.comment: Collect Service Pack version
DEPPrevention must be configured as 13013

metadata.title: The "DisableAddressSharing" Registry parameter should be set to "1" on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "DisableAddressSharing" parameter defines whether the system will allow sharing addresses between processes. When enabled, the system will not allow a process to share the same socket with another process. Not protecting against this type of share may allow attackers to gain access to data from the process currently using the address.

criterion.comment: DisableAddressSharing must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The NTFS permission for the "%SystemRoot%\System32\drivers\etc\hosts" file should be set up so as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The Hosts file is responsible for mapping IP addresses to Host names. It is recommended that access permissions be set up so as to prevent unauthorized access. Attackers may change this file inadvertently so that a given Host name points to a location containing malicious code.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\System32\drivers\etc\hosts - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\System32\drivers\etc\hosts - Read and Execute permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\System32\drivers\etc\hosts - SID's Verification

metadata.title: The Windows XP "Turn off printing over HTTP" parameter should be enabled.
metadata.description: The "Turn off printing over HTTP" parameter defines whether or not the system will allow transmitting documents to the printer over HTTP. In case the transmission is made through this protocol, it will be unencrypted and may be easily intercepted by attackers using a "sniffer" tool. Therefore, it is recommended that the "Turn off printing over HTTP" parameter be enabled.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
DisableHTTPPrint must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "System objects: Strengthen default permissions of internal system objects (e.g. symbolic links)" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "System objects: Strengthen default permissions of internal system objects (e.g. symbolic links)" parameter determines the restriction level of the objects' default "discretionary access control list" (DACL). Windows XP keeps a global list of shared system resources, such as the names of DOS devices and "semaphores". In this way, objects can be found and shared between processes. Each type of object is created with a default DACL that specifies who can access the object, and with which permissions. If this parameter is enabled, the restriction level of the default DACL will be increased, to allow non-administrative users just read-only access on shared objects.

criterion.comment: StrgPermissionSystem must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "Hidden" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "Hidden" parameter determines whether the system will send messages to the network's "Master Browser", to inform this browser of its presence. The "Master Browser" gathers information about all the computers present on the network and issues a "Browse List" with this information. To prevent attackers from gaining access to the names of the computers on the network, it is recommended that the system be set up to not send messages to the "Master Browser".

criterion.comment: Hidden must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "DisableBasicOverClearChannel" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "DisableBasicOverClearChannel" parameter defines whether the system will allow the use of the "BasicAuth" user authentication for all websites that require this method of authentication. This form of authentication sends the user credentials in cleartext (user name and password) to the server. As a result, this information can be easily viewed by attackers and later used to carry out attacks. For this reason, it is recommended that the system be configured to not use the "BasicAuth" form of authentication.

criterion.comment: registry key exist?
DisableBasicOverClearChannel must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The "WriteProtect" Registry parameter should be set to "1" on Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "Write Protect" parameter defines whether storage devices connected to the computer's USB port will be set up as read-only. Therefore, no information can be copied onto these devices, which, in turn, prevents the theft of information.

criterion.comment: WriteProtect must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The Windows XP "Turn on Security Center (Domain PCs only)" parameter should be enabled.
metadata.description: When the "Turn on Security Center (Domain PCs only)" parameter is enabled, warnings will be displayed to the user in case of security issues with the anti-virus software, Windows Firewall and Windows Update. Therefore, it is recommended to enable the "Turn on Security Center (Domain PCs only)" parameter.

criterion.comment: SecurityCenter must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The Windows XP "Do not process the run once list" parameter should be enabled.
metadata.description: The "Do not process the run once list" parameter defines whether or not Windows will execute the commands present in the "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\RunOnce" Registry parameter. This Registry parameter is typically used by program installs that need to run certain tasks after the computer has been restarted for the first time. In order to prevent attackers from running malicious programs using this Registry parameter, it is recommended to set up Windows so that it will not execute the commands included in that parameter.

criterion.comment: RunOnceList must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The Windows XP "Do not allow passwords to be saved" parameter should be enabled.
metadata.description: The "Do not allow passwords to be saved" parameter defines whether or not the user credentials utilized to log onto other computers through the Terminal Services Client will be stored in the computer. In order to prevent the user credentials from being stored, it is recommended to enable this parameter.

criterion.comment: PasswordSaving must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The Windows XP "Do not allow drive redirection" parameter should be enabled.
metadata.description: The "Do not allow drive redirection" parameter defines whether or not Terminal Services Client users may share the local disk units with the Terminal Server. Whenever the disk units are shared, they become vulnerable and can be accessed by attackers. Therefore, it is recommended to enable this parameter.

criterion.comment: fDisableCdm must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "EnableFragmentChecking" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "EnableFragmentChecking" parameter is used to check on the packets received via a network. This check verifies whether the packet is fragmented or not. The fragmented ones are discarded. Receiving fragmented packets uses system resources excessively. Moreover, attackers can use this flaw to make the system unavailable by launching Denial of Service attacks against it. For these reasons, it is recommended that fragment checking be enabled.

criterion.comment: EnableFragmentChecking must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "EnablePMTUDiscovery" Registry parameter should be set as follows: "0"
metadata.description: The "EnablePMTUDiscovery" parameter defines whether the TCP protocol will use a fixed MTU value or whether it will attempt to detect the current setting. It is recommended that the parameter be set to "0" in order to determine a fixed MTU value for all packets. This will reduce package fragmentation at routers connecting several networks with different MTU settings. An excess of fragmented packages on a network may degrade network performance.

criterion.comment: EnablePMTUDiscovery must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "NoNameReleaseOnDemand" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "NoNameReleaseOnDemand" parameter determines whether the system will renew its NetBIOS name when a name-release request is received. It is recommended that this parameter be set to "1" in order to avoid replacing the system's NetBIOS name. The NetBIOS protocol does not make use of authentication. Because of that, attackers can send name-release packets to the system to create name-conflicts within the network, thus causing system unavailability.

criterion.comment: NoNameReleaseOnDemand must be configured as 1

metadata.title: The "Timeout" parameter in the Registry should be set to "0".
metadata.description: The "Timeout" parameter is responsible for the execution of the "DirectDraw" API. "DirectDraw" is used by professional graphics applications and games.
