metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\net.exe" and "%SystemRoot%\system32\net1.exe" files should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\net.exe" and "%SystemRoot%\system32\net1.exe" programs are used for managing workstations, servers and other systems. Through these programs, user accounts can be added, altered or removed, for example. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run these programs, he would be able to carry out administrative operations on the system, which could lead to security breaches being exploited in future attacks. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\net.exe and %SystemRoot%\system32\net1.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\net.exe and %SystemRoot%\system32\net1.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\tlntsvr.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\tlntsvr.exe" program is used to start a Telnet server on the system. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he could start a Telnet server on the system to have connections established. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\tlntsvr.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\tlntsvr.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\tftp.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\tftp.exe" program is used to connect the system to a TFTP server. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to access this file, he would be able to connect to TFTP servers storing malicious code. This would enable this user to install malicious code on the system with the intention of breaching system security. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\tftp.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\tftp.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: Windows XP's "Windows Firewall: Protect all network connections" parameter should be enabled.
metadata.description: The "Windows Firewall: Protect all network connections" parameter determines whether the Windows Firewall should be enabled. It is recommended that the Windows Firewall be enabled to prevent attackers from obtaining access to the computer through service ports and other security breaches.

criterion.comment: EnableFirewall from Domain and Standard Profile must be configured as 1
Collect Service Pack version

metadata.title: The Windows XP "Windows Firewall: Allow local program exceptions" parameter should be disabled.
metadata.description: The "Windows Firewall: Allow local program exceptions" parameter defines whether or not local computer administrators may create rules of exception for the computer programs. It is recommended that this parameter be disabled so as to prevent users or attackers from creating rules that allow unauthorized access to the system.

criterion.comment: Windows Firewall: Allow local program exceptions must be configured as 0
Windows Firewall: Allow local program exceptions must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The parameter "System objects: Default owner for objects created by members of the Administrators group" should be configured as "Object Creator".
metadata.description: The parameter "System objects: Default owner for objects created by members of the Administrators group" determines who will be the default owner of all of the objects (folders or files, for instance) created by users of the "Administrators" group. It is recommended to configure this parameter so that objects created by these users are owned by their own creator in order to prevent users of the "Administrators" group from gaining access to created objects.

criterion.comment: System objects: Default owner for objects created by members of the Administrators group must be configured as Object Creator

metadata.title: Windows XP's time synchronization service should be configured as requiring authentication.
metadata.description: The "type" parameter determines how the Windows XP's time synchronization service will work, that is, if it will use authentication or not. It is recommended that this service work using authentication, thus stopping attackers from changing the date and time of the system. Non-authorized modifications of the date and time of the system may cause inconsistencies in the audit trails.

criterion.comment: HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services\W32Time\Parameters\type must be configured as Nt5DS

metadata.title: The "Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Domain member: Require strong (Windows 2000 or later) session key" parameter determines whether all traffic in a secure channel will need a strong encryption key (Windows 2000 or later), thus better protecting the data being transmitted. When this parameter is disabled, the key to be used during the session is negotiated with the Domain Controller (DC).

criterion.comment: The parameter RequireStrongKey must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: The Windows XP administrative shares should be disabled.
metadata.description: Microsoft operating systems based on the NT platform create, by default, administrative shares for every disk drive available on the computer. As the term indicates, these shares have an administrative function and, through them, it is possible to access without restrictions all files on the disk. If they are removed using the normal procedures, they will be recreated when the system is restarted. It is recommended that these shares be disabled in order to prevent attackers from accessing the system without permission.

criterion.comment: The parameter AutoShareWks must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "Interactive logon: Require domain controller authentication to unlock workstation" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: When disabled, The "Interactive logon: Require domain controller authentication to unlock workstation" parameter allows a user to unlock his or her workstation even when the domain controller is inaccessible for whatever reason. It is recommended that this option be enabled so as to prevent the system from storing system user credentials, since this would facilitate brute force and dictionary password-cracking attacks.

criterion.comment: The parameter forceunlocklogon must be configured different from 0

metadata.title: Windows XP automatic logon should be disabled.
metadata.description: The "autologon" feature allows users to access the operating system without having to inform valid names and passwords. The authentication is performed automatically, based on user credentials previously stored in the Windows' cache. It is recommended that this feature be disabled wherever possible to reduce the risks of non-authorized access by unauthorized users who happen to have physical access to the computer.

criterion.comment: The parameter HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\LogonType must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "TcpMaxHalfOpen" registry parameter should be set to "100" in Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "TcpMaxHalfOpen" parameter defines the maximum number of "SYN-RCVD" connections. Whenever the number defined in the parameter is reached, the "SynAttack" protection mechanism is executed. In case this parameter is not set up, the system may be subject to denial of service attacks, which in turn may degrade system performance and, consequently, make the system unavailable.

criterion.comment: The parameter HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters\TcpMaxHalfOpen must be configured as 100
The parameter HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters\SynAttackProtect must be configured as 1 or 2

metadata.title: The "TcpMaxHalfOpenRetired" registry parameter should be set to "80" in Windows XP.
metadata.description: The "TcpMaxHalfOpenRetired" parameter defines the maximum number of "SYN-RCVD" connections that have performed at least one "SYN" packet re-transmission. Whenever the number defined in the parameter is reached, the "SynAttack" protection mechanism is executed. In case this parameter is not set up, the system may be subject to denial of service attacks, which in turn may degrade system performance and, consequently, make the system unavailable.

criterion.comment: The parameter HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters\TcpMaxHalfOpenRetried must be configured as 80
The parameter HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Services\Tcpip\Parameters\SynAttackProtect must be configured as 1 or 2

metadata.title: The Windows XP "Windows Firewall: Allow local port exceptions" parameter should be disabled.
metadata.description: The "Windows Firewall: Allow local port exceptions" parameter defines whether or not local computer administrators may create exception rules for the computer ports. It is recommended that this parameter be disabled so as to prevent users or attackers from creating rules that allow unauthorized access to the system.

criterion.comment: The parameter HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Policies\Microsoft\WindowsFirewall\StandardProfile\GloballyOpenPorts\AllowUserPrefMerge must be configured as 0
The parameter HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\Software\Policies\Microsoft\WindowsFirewall\DomainProfile\GloballyOpenPorts\AllowUserPrefMerge must be configured as 0

metadata.title: The "RestrictGuestAccess" parameter in the Registry should be set to "1".
metadata.description: The "RestrictGuestAccess" parameter determines whether anonymous access to the audit files will be enabled. When set to "1", anonymous access is disabled. It is recommended that anonymous access be disabled in order to prevent attackers from accessing the system's audit records.

criterion.comment: RestrictGuestAccess = Value Data '1' to be implemented.

metadata.title: The "Interactive logon: Message text for users attempting to log on" should be configured with a warning message about the unauthorized use of the system.
metadata.description: The "Interactive logon: Message text for users attempting to log on" parameter enables you to save a message box's text containing a warning. The goal is to make it clear that the computer onto which the user intends to log belongs to the organization and that its use is restricted to authorized users only. From the legal standpoint, it is advisable to explicitly state that unauthorized users are not welcome, that unauthorized access to the system will be recorded, and that any unauthorized access attempt could have serious consequences.

criterion.comment: The parameter Interactive logon: Message text for users attempting to log on must be configured with a warning about the bad use of the system.

metadata.title: The "Interactive logon: Message title for users attempting to log on" parameter should be configured with a sentence that clarifies the purpose of the warning message.
metadata.description: The "Interactive logon: Message title for users attempting to log on" parameter enables you to save the title of a message box containing a warning. The goal is to make it clear that the computer onto which the user intends to log belongs to the organization and is restricted to authorized users only.

criterion.comment: The parameter Interactive logon: Message title for users attempting to log on must be configured with a phrase that clarifies the warning message.

metadata.title: The "OS/2" subsystem should be removed from Windows XP.
metadata.description: The aim of the OS/2 subsystem is to make Windows compatible with OS/2 applications. In Windows XP, the OS/2 subsystem can cause an undesirable situation whereby an application or process initiated under the context of a user persists in the system even after his or her logout. This way, non-authorized access to the system can occur by means of persistent processes running under the context of a user who has already terminated his session. As a good security practice, it is recommended that the optional OS/2 subsystem be removed wherever possible.

criterion.comment: The subsystem OS/2 must be removed from Windows XP.
The parameter HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Environment\Os2LibPath can't exist.
The parameter HKLM\Software\Microsoft\OS/2 can't exist.

metadata.title: The "POSIX" subsystem should be removed from Windows XP.
metadata.description: The aim of subsystem POSIX is to make Windows compatible with the POSIX standard. However, this can cause undesirable situations with respect to the proper functioning of the system. POSIX applications distinguish between files having the same name but with different letter sizes, as in "file.txt" and "FILE.TXT". For Windows applications though, these files would not be distinguished from each other. An attacker could take advantage of this situation to trick the system by creating new files using the names of already existing important ones, although with different letter sizes. This could make the system access forged files. As a good security practice, it is recommended that the optional POSIX subsystem be removed in case it is not strictly needed.

criterion.comment: Check if 'HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Subsystems\Optional' is different from 'Posix'
Check if 'HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Session Manager\Subsystems\Posix' exist, if so test is false, else test is true
Check if %SystemRoot%\system32\posix.exe and psxss.exe exist, if so test is false, else test is true

metadata.title: The "Act as part of the operating system" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Act as part of the operating system" parameter allows full access to the operating system, having precedence over any other right, permission or privilege. Processes that may require this level of access should use the "LocalSystem" account, which already has this right. Under normal circumstances, this privilege should not be given to any user.

criterion.comment: The parameter Act as part of the operating system must be configured for no one

metadata.title: The "Create a token object" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Create a token object" parameter specifies which accounts can be used by a process to create a "security access token" with a view to allowing access to local resources when the process uses the "NtCreateToken()" function or another function for creating "tokens" from the API. For greater security, Microsoft recommends that processes that require this privilege use the "LocalSystem" account (an account that already has this privilege), instead of assigning it to users.

criterion.comment: The parameter Create a token object must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Create permanent shared objects" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Create permanent shared objects" parameter allows a process to create a directory object in the "Windows XP Object Manager". This functionality is only necessary for some components of the Windows "Kernel", and as the components that run in "Kernel-mode" already have this privilege, it is neither necessary nor recommended to grant this privilege to users.

criterion.comment: The parameter Create permanent shared objects must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Debug programs" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Debug programs" parameter specifies which accounts can connect a "debugger" to a process. The right to debug allows the user to access the operating system memory content, which may contain sensitive information. Informed users can also use debugging to modify software in order to run malicious code. Also, accidental mistakes made during debugging may render the system unavailable. For this reason, this privilege should not be assigned to any users.

criterion.comment: The parameter Debug programs must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Deny logon as a service" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Deny logon as a service" parameter specifies which accounts are not allowed to log on as an operating system service, so establishing a security context. For instance, if a service is started under the context of a domain user account, then an attacker capable of exploiting some vulnerability of this service will be able to gain access to the domain's resources under the context of the account used. The "LocalSystem" account always has the right to log on as a service. Unless strictly necessary, it is recommended that the default value, as specified in the control be kept. This parameter has precedence over the "Log on as a service" parameter in case of conflicting settings.

criterion.comment: The parameter Deny log on as a service must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Force shutdown from a remote system" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Force shutdown from a remote system" parameter specifies which users are allowed to turn off the computer from a remote system. Misusing this privilege may render the computer services unavailable.

criterion.comment: The parameter Force shutdown from a remote system must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Force shutdown from a remote system must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Increase scheduling priority" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Increase scheduling priority" parameter specifies which accounts can alter the running priority of a process through the "Task Manager". The abuse of this privilege can cause a degradation in performance of other processes, and in certain cases may even lead to services becoming unavailable.

criterion.comment: The parameter Increase scheduling priority must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Increase scheduling priority must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Load and unload device drivers" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Load and unload device drivers" parameter specifies which accounts can dynamically load and unload "Plug and Play" device drivers. As "device drivers" are run with high privileges on the system, the abuse of this right can allow the installation of malicious code, leading to information being compromised and to the system becoming unavailable.

criterion.comment: The parameter Load and unload device drivers must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Load and unload device drivers must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Log on as a service" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Log on as a service" parameter specifies which accounts are allowed to log on as an operating system service, so establishing a security context. For instance, if a service is started under the context of a domain user account, then an attacker capable of exploiting some vulnerability of this service will be able to gain access to the domain's resources under the context of the account used. The "LocalSystem" account always has the right to log on as a service. Other accounts that are used to start services also need to be able to log on as a service. With the exception of the aforementioned accounts, or only when strictly necessary, it is recommended that the default value of "No user" be kept. This right should not be assigned to any user account.

criterion.comment: The parameter Log on as a service must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Manage auditing and security log" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Manage auditing and security log" parameter specifies which accounts are allowed to use the "Security" tab in the properties of objects such as files, "Active Directory" objects and Registry keys, in order to specify auditing options to be used during access operations to these resources. A user with this privilege can also read and erase entries in the security "log" using the "Event Viewer". As the security "log" holds sensitive information, this privilege should be restricted to the administrators.

criterion.comment: The parameter Manage auditing and security log must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Manage auditing and security log must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Modify firmware environment values" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Modify firmware environment values" parameter specifies which accounts are allowed to alter system variables, by using the "System Properties" or by other means. By "default", only administrators and the "LocalSystem" account have this privilege. The "default" value should be kept wherever possible, as unauthorized alteration of system variables could cause problems in applications.

criterion.comment: The parameter Modify firmware environment values must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Modify firmware environment values must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Profile system performance" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Profile system performance" parameter specifies which accounts are allowed to use the Windows NT, Windows 2000 and Windows XP "System Monitor" tools for monitoring the performance of processes running on the system. Information on the state of system processes should be classified as restricted information. Therefore, this right should be restricted to administrators and to the "LocalSystem" account.

criterion.comment: The parameter Profile system performance must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Profile system performance must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Restore files and directories" parameter should be set to "Administrators" and "Backup Operators".
metadata.description: The "Restore files and directories" parameter specifies which accounts are allowed to bypass file and directory permissions when restoring files and directories from a backup. As this right has precedence over NTFS permissions and allows access to the entire file system, it should only be granted to totally trustworthy users who are part of groups with administrative responsibilities.

criterion.comment: The parameter Restore files and directories must be configured as Administrators and Backup Operators.
The parameter Restore files and directories must be configured as Administrators and Backup Operators.
The parameter Restore files and directories must be configured as Administrators and Backup Operators.

metadata.title: The "Shut down the system" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Shut down the system" parameter specifies which accounts can shut the system down. Unauthorized use of this right could render the system unavailable. Therefore, this right should only be granted to trustworthy users who participate is some way in the server administration.

criterion.comment: All users except Administrators and Users seshutdownprivilege = 0
Administrators seshutdownprivilege = 1.
Users seshutdownprivilege = 1

metadata.title: The "Take ownership of files or other objects" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Take ownership of files or other objects" parameter specifies which accounts are allowed take ownership of "Active Directory" objects, files, directories, printers, Registry keys, processes and other objects. Abuse of this right could lead to unauthorized access to confidential information, frauds and other security problems.

criterion.comment: The parameter Take ownership of files or other objects must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Take ownership of files or other objects must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Profile single process" parameter should be set as "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Profile single process" parameter determines which user accounts can use the Windows NT, Windows 2000 and Windows XP monitoring tools to monitor non-system processes. The status of critical processes may be considered restricted information, therefore only administrators should have this right.

criterion.comment: The parameter Profile single process must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Profile single process must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Lock pages in memory" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Lock pages in memory" parameter specifies which accounts can make the system keep processes in physical memory ("RAM"), preventing them from being moved to the virtual memory. It is recommended that this right be restricted to certain accounts or user groups, to prevent attackers from launching Denial-of-Service attacks that use up the system's physical memory and make the system unavailable.

criterion.comment: The parameter Lock pages in memory must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "TCPMaxPortsExhausted" Registry parameter should be set to "5".
metadata.description: The "TCPMaxPortsExhausted" parameter is used to define how many discarded connections can take place before the protection mechanism against Syn-Flood attacks is activated. It is recommended to set this parameter to "5", so that the mechanism can be activated after the fifth discarded connection, thus avoiding a slowdown in system performance or system downtime.

criterion.comment: 'TCPMaxPortsExhausted' must be equal to 5.

metadata.title: The "Perform volume maintenance tasks" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Perform volume maintenance tasks" parameter defines which user accounts or user groups - other than system administrators or remote users - may manage system volumes or disks, which attackers may modify by deleting sensitive information or rendering the system unavailable by deleting an entire volume. Therefore, it is recommended that only authorized administrators be allowed to manage system volumes or disks.

criterion.comment: The parameter Perform volume maintenance tasks must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Perform volume maintenance tasks must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Create a pagefile" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Create a pagefile" parameter determines which user accounts can create and change the "pagefile" size. The "pagefile" size should be proportionate to the amount of system memory. Incorrect size settings can lead to low performance, application issues or even make the system unavailable. Therefore, this privilege should be assigned to administrators only.

criterion.comment: The parameter Create a pagefile must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Create a pagefile must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Back up files and directories" parameter should be set to "Administrators" and "Backup Operators".
metadata.description: The "Back up files and directories" parameter determines which accounts can have access to the file system for backup purposes, regardless of the NTFS permissions. In other words, this right takes precedence over NTFS permissions on directories and files. Therefore, it should only be granted to administrators and backup operators.

criterion.comment: The parameter Back up files and directories must be configured as Administrators and Backup Operators.
The parameter Back up files and directories must be configured as Administrators and Backup Operators.
The parameter Back up files and directories must be configured as Administrators and Backup Operators.

metadata.title: The "Change the system time" parameter should be set to "Administrators"
metadata.description: The "Change the system time" parameter determines which accounts are allowed to change the date and time of the system's internal clock. Incorrect configuration of the date and time can create numerous problems for applications and compromise the validity of audit records, besides creating problems for Kerberos-based authentication. Therefore, this privilege should only be assigned to administrators and authorized users.

criterion.comment: The parameter Change the system time must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Change the system time must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Generate security audits" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Generate security audits" parameter allows a process to write security-related entries to the security log. No user should have this privilege. Otherwise, attackers would be able to create an excessive amount of entries in the security log with the intention of making the system unavailable.

criterion.comment: The parameter Generate security audits must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Remove computer from docking station" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Remove computer from docking station" parameter determines which users or user groups are allowed to remove the computer from its docking station. Only authorized users should have this privilege so that unauthorized users will be prevented from removing the computer from its docking station.

criterion.comment: The parameter Remove computer from docking station must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Replace a process level token" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Replace a process level token" parameter specifies which user accounts can initiate a process to replace the default token associated with a launched subprocess. Abuse of this right allows the replacement of a token that controls access to a process with another token, which could lead to the system being compromised. By default, only the "LocalSystem" account has this privilege, which under normal conditions should not be granted to any user.

criterion.comment: The parameter Replace a process level token must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Create global objects" parameter should be set to "Administrators" and "Service".
metadata.description: The "Create global objects" parameter determines which user accounts have the right to create global objects that can be accessed by all sessions running on the computer. Only administrators and system services should be included in this parameter. This would help prevent attackers from creating objects that could generate errors in the applications in use, causing their unavailability.

criterion.comment: The parameter Create global objects must be configured as Administrators and Service.
The parameter Create global objects must be configured as Administrators and Service.
The parameter Create global objects must be configured as Administrators and Service.

metadata.title: The "Adjust memory quotas for a process" parameter should be set to "Administrators".
metadata.description: The "Adjust memory quotas for a process" parameter determines which accounts are able to increase the processor (CPU) quota that is allocated to processes running on the system. This privilege is useful when tuning the system becomes necessary. However, its improper use might facilitate denial of service attacks. For this reason, it should be restricted to administrators.

criterion.comment: The parameter Adjust memory quotas for a process must be configured as Administrators.
The parameter Adjust memory quotas for a process must be configured as Administrators.

metadata.title: The "Allow logon through Terminal Services" parameter should be set to "No Users".
metadata.description: The "Allow logon through Terminal Services" parameter determines which user accounts or groups will have access to the computer through the Terminal Services. Terminal Services are used for remote assistance, enabling a user to connect to a remote computer in order to solve a problem. By means of these services, it is possible to view the desktop or any other part of the system. Wherever possible, only system administrators should have this privilege. This prevents attackers from obtaining unauthorized access to the system.

criterion.comment: The parameter Allow logon through Terminal Services must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Deny logon through Terminal Services" parameter should be set to "Everyone".
metadata.description: The "Deny logon through Terminal Services" parameter determines which user accounts will not have access to the system through the Terminal Services. However, they will be able to log on to the system locally. Other services, such as Telnet and SMB, will still be accessible. If possible, this parameter should be configured in a way that does not allow anyone to connect to the system via Terminal Services.

criterion.comment: The parameter Deny logon through Terminal Services must be configured as Everyone.
The parameter Deny logon through Terminal Services must be configured as Everyone.

metadata.title: The "Impersonate a client after authentication" parameter should be set to "Service".
metadata.description: The "Impersonate a client after authentication" parameter specifies which users will have permission to run a program using the privileges of the user account to which the start of this program was assigned. In this way, users included in this parameter will be able to use it to gain more privileges on the system, possibly obtaining administrative privileges. Wherever possible, it is recommended that no users or groups have this right so that attackers are prevented from gaining non-authorized access to the system.

criterion.comment: All except Administrators and Service seimpersonateprivilege = 0
Administrators seimpersonateprivilege = 1.
Service seimpersonateprivilege = 1

metadata.title: The "Deny access to this computer from the network" parameter should be set to "Guest" and "Support_388945a0".
metadata.description: The "Deny access to this computer from the network" parameter specifies which accounts or user groups are not allowed to access the system from the network. This way, users included in this parameter will not be able to access this computer's shared resources (files, printers, etc). For generic environments, it is recommended that the "Guest" and "Support_388945a0" accounts be included in this parameter, otherwise it will be impossible to trace the person who have used these accounts, leading to a loss of traceability.

criterion.comment: The parameter Deny access to this computer from the network must be configured as Guest and Support_388945a0.
The parameter Deny access to this computer from the network must be configured as Guest and Support_388945a0.
The parameter Deny access to this computer from the network must be configured as Guest and Support_388945a0.

metadata.title: The "Access this computer from the network" parameter should be set to "Administrators" and "Users".
metadata.description: The "Access this computer from the network" parameter determines which users and groups are granted permission to connect to the computer through the network (for example, to access shared folders). By default, this privilege is granted to the "Everyone" group, but this setting is very permissive and facilitates certain types of remote attacks. The proper setting of this right depends very much upon the characteristics of the environment.

criterion.comment: The parameter Access this computer from the network must be configured as Administrators and Users.
The parameter Access this computer from the network must be configured as Administrators and Users.
The parameter Access this computer from the network must be configured as Administrators and Users.

metadata.title: The "Bypass traverse checking" parameter should be set to "Users".
metadata.description: The "Bypass traverse checking" parameter specifies which accounts can access subdirectories even without having permissions on the parent directory. This privilege does not allow the user to list the content of a directory, and should be granted to all users. Otherwise, important applications and files may become inaccessible.

criterion.comment: The 'Bypass traverse checking' parameter must be set to 0 to All, under Users.
The 'Bypass traverse checking' parameter must be set to 1 for Users.

metadata.title: The "Allow log on Locally" parameter should be set to "Administrators" and "Users".
metadata.description: The "Allow log on locally" parameter specifies which users have the right to log on locally to the computer. Access to the console exposes the system to attacks that can only be made through local logons (for example, gaining administrative privileges by using "exploits" such as "GetAdmin").

criterion.comment: The parameter Access this computer from the network must be configured as Administrators and Users.
The parameter Access this computer from the network must be configured as Administrators and Users.
The parameter Access this computer from the network must be configured as Administrators and Users.

metadata.title: The "Deny log on as a batch job" parameter should be set to "Guest".
metadata.description: The "Deny log on as a batch job" parameter specifies which accounts are not allowed to log on to the system by means of a job scheduled for future execution (for instance, through the "task scheduler"). It takes precedence over the "Log on as a batch job" parameter in the case of conflicting settings. It is recommended that the "Guest" account be included in this parameter to prevent attempts to gain unauthorized access through this account.

criterion.comment: The parameter Deny log on as a batch job must be configured as Guest.
The parameter Deny log on as a batch job must be configured as Guest.

metadata.title: The "Log on as a batch job" parameter should be set to "No user".
metadata.description: The "Log on as a batch job" parameter specifies which accounts can be authenticated on the system through a "job" scheduled for later execution, for example: when a user schedules a task through the "task scheduler", the system executes the task authenticating the user as a "batch user" instead of as a traditional interactive user. Task scheduling allows equipment to be manipulated at specified times, or for tasks to be executed sequentially without the need for the user to be "on-line" at the time of execution. This means that task scheduling is a powerful weapon in the hands of malicious users. For example, a remote user with task scheduling privileges could schedule file transfers or the creation or removal of users on the system to be executed at a determined time when the monitoring of the environment is less intense. Wherever possible, this privilege should not be assigned to any user.

criterion.comment: The parameter Log on as a batch job must be configured for no one.

metadata.title: The "Deny log on locally" parameter should be set to "Guest".
metadata.description: The "Deny log on locally" parameter specifies which user accounts are not allowed to log on to the computer locally. In the case of conflicting settings, it takes precedence over the "Log on Locally" parameter. It is recommended that the "Guest" account be included in this parameter to prevent attempts to gain unauthorized access through this account.

criterion.comment: The parameter Deny log on locally must be configured as Guest.
The parameter Deny log on locally must be configured as Guest.

metadata.title: Windows XP should be set up to not allow recent passwords to be reused.
metadata.description: The "Enforce Password History" determines the number of different passwords that must be used before a user is allowed to repeat a previous password. This parameter accepts values between "0" and "24". The continuous and prolonged use of the same password by a user facilitates password-cracking attacks using brute force or dictionary techniques. This could lead to unauthorized access to the system. The value used must be in accordance with the Security Policy. As good practice for generic environments, the system should not allow the user to re-use any of the last 24 passwords.

criterion.comment: The procedure to prevent the recent passwords reuse should be implemented in Windows Server 2008.

metadata.title: The "Maximum Password Age" parameter should be set to a value between "30" and "90".
metadata.description: The "Maximum Password Age" parameter defines the number of days that a password can be used before expiring. Prolonged use of the same password by a user facilitates password-cracking attacks using brute force or dictionary techniques. This can lead to unauthorized access to the system. This parameter accepts a value between "1" and "999" (days). The value to which this parameter is set should comply with the Security Policy in use. As a general recommendation, a value between "30" and "90" days is suggested.

criterion.comment: The parameter Maximum Password Age must be configured between 30 and 90.
The parameter Maximum Password Age must be configured between 30 and 90.

metadata.title: The "Minimum Password Age" parameter should be set to a value of "1".
metadata.description: The "Minimum Password Age" parameter determines the number of days that a password must be used before it can be changed by the user. It is recommended that only more-than-one-day-old passwords be allowed to change. This prevents users from repetitively changing passwords in order to reuse an older password. Repetitively switching passwords tricks the organization's password-reuse policy. Also, the user may be reusing a password already obtained by attackers.

criterion.comment: The parameter Minimum Password Age must be configured as 1.

metadata.title: The "Minimum Password Length" parameter should be set to a value of "14".
metadata.description: The "Minimum Password Length" parameter establishes the minimum number of characters a password must have. It accepts a value between "0" and "14". If it is set to "0", the users of the computer will not need to have passwords. The use of easy-to-guess passwords make Windows XP systems vulnerable to unauthorized access by unauthorized users who benefit from password-cracking attacks that use dictionary and brute force techniques. This parameter should comply with the Security Policy. As a generic recommendation, passwords must be at least 14 characters long.

criterion.comment: The parameter Minimum Password Length must be configured as 14.

metadata.title: The "Passwords must meet complexity requirements" parameter should be set to "Enabled".
metadata.description: The "Passwords must meet complexity requirements" parameter implements the use of a filter ("passfilt.dll") that prevents users from choosing certain combinations of characters that would result in weak passwords. The use of weak passwords (that is, easy to guess) make Windows XP systems vulnerable to unauthorized access by unauthorized users who benefit from password-cracking attacks that use dictionary and brute force techniques.

criterion.comment: The parameter Passwords must meet complexity requirements must be configured as Enabled.

metadata.title: The "Store passwords using reversible encryption" parameter should be set to "Disabled".
metadata.description: The "Store passwords using reversible encryption" parameter allows user passwords to be easily decrypted, facilitating a higher degree of compatibility with third-party applications. If this parameter is enabled, the confidentiality of user information is compromised. There may be unauthorized access to the system, since user passwords are not properly protected.

criterion.comment: The parameter Store passwords using reversible encryption must be configured as Disabled.

metadata.title: A user account lockout mechanism that blocks the account after a certain number of unsuccessful logon attempts should be implemented on Windows Vista systems.
metadata.description: The "Account lockout threshold" determines the number of invalid logon attempts allowed before the user account is blocked. Without this mechanism, user accounts and those accounts used to start services will be indefinitely exposed to password-cracking attacks using brute force and dictionary techniques. Blocking accounts after a certain number of failed login attempts protects user passwords from attacks of this type. This parameter accepts a value between "1" and "999" (number of attempts). It should comply with the Security Policy, but a value of "3" is appropriate for most organizations.

criterion.comment: The mechanism for blocking accounts after a certain number of unsuccessful logon attempts should be implemented.

metadata.title: The "Account lockout duration" parameter should be set to a value of "15".
metadata.description: The "Account lockout duration" parameter defines how long an account blocked by the "Account Lockout" mechanism must remain blocked. In some circumstances, an attacker may be able to force all user accounts to be blocked. As a result, if only the administrator were to be capable of unlocking the accounts, a great amount of work would have to be performed to have all of them unlocked. This would make the period of time in which these accounts remain unavailable considerably longer. For this reason, in generic environments, user accounts should be blocked for no less than 15 minutes. This parameter accepts a value between "1" and "99999" (minutes).

criterion.comment: The parameter Account lockout duration must be configured as 15.

metadata.title: The "Reset account lockout counter after" parameter should be set to a value above "15".
metadata.description: The "Reset account lockout counter after" parameter defines the number of minutes it takes for the invalid login attempts counter to return to zero. This parameter accepts a value between "1" and "99999" (minutes). For generic environments, a value above "15" is recommended.

criterion.comment: The parameter Reset account lockout counter after must be configured greater than 15.

metadata.title: The "HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurePipeServers\winreg" Registry Key should have its permissions set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurePipeServers\winreg" key specifies which users will have remote access to the Registry. It is recommended that only authorized administrative users be allowed to access it. This would help prevent attackers or any other users from modifying the Registry in a way that could either lead to security breaches being exploited in future attacks or make the system unavailable.

criterion.comment: The 'HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurePipeServers\winreg' Registry Key should have its permissions set so as to prevent unauthorized access.
The 'HKLM\System\CurrentControlSet\Control\SecurePipeServers\winreg' Registry Key should have its permissions set so as to prevent unauthorized access. -SID's Verification

metadata.title: The "HK_CLASSES_ROOT" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HK_CLASSES_ROOT" registry key is used to map file extensions to programs so that when a file is opened the right program is executed. Attackers can modify these mappings with the intention of running programs containing malicious code. This way, they would be able to breach security, facilitating future attacks. For this reason, permissions on this registry key should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HK_CLASSES_ROOT' Registry key should have its permission set as Adiministrators and System = Full Controll
The 'HK_CLASSES_ROOT' Registry key should have its permission set as CREATOR OWNER = None
The 'HK_CLASSES_ROOT' Registry key should have its permission set as Users = Read
SID's Verification - Administrators, CREATOR OWNER, SYSTEM, Users.

metadata.title: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE" Registry key is used to store information regarding the configuration of the software that has been installed on the computer. Attackers can make unauthorized changes to configuration settings of installed software rendering it unavailable. Among the unauthorized modifications that can be made, we can highlight the possibility of having the installed antivirus software disabled on the computer. For this reason, permissions on this registry key should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE' Registry key should have its permission set as Administrators and SYSTEM = Full Control.
The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE' Registry key should have its permission set as CREATOR OWNER = None.
The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE' Registry key should have its permission set as Users = Read.
SID's Verification - Administrators, System, CREATOR OWNER, Users.

metadata.title: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\NetDDE" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\NetDDE" Registry key is used to store information regarding the "NDDE" ("Network Dynamic Data Exchange") protocol. This protocol is employed by applications to exchange data. To prevent attackers from making unauthorized changes to these configuration settings with the intention of making this protocol unavailable, the permissions on this key should be set up in such a way as to block unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\NetDDE' Registry key should have its permission so as to prevent unauthorized access

metadata.title: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Perflib" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Perflib" Registry key stores parameters used by the Performance Monitor's library. Performance Monitor is a tool that gathers information about the system such as the size of the virtual memory, for example. To prevent unauthorized changes from being made to the Performance Monitor's configuration settings, which would compromise the information gathered by the tool, the access permissions on this key should be set up in such a way as to block unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Perflib' Registry key should have its permission set to Administrators and SYSTEM = Full Control.
The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Perflib' Registry key should have its permission set to CREATOR OWNER = None.
The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Perflib' Registry key should have its permission set to INTERACTIVE = Read.
SID's Verification - Administrators, CREATOR OWNER, SYSTEM, INTERACTIVE.

metadata.title: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Group Policy" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Group Policy" Registry key is used to store configuration information regarding Windows Group Policies. Attackers can make unauthorized changes to the configuration settings of Group Policies, which could lead to security breaches being exploited in future attacks. For this reason, permissions on this registry key should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Check if HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Group Policy Registry Key exists.
The HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Group Policy Registry Key should have its permissions set up as Administrators = Full Control SYSTEM = Full Control
The HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Group Policy Registry Key should have its permissions set up as Authenticated Users = Read
possible Sids

metadata.title: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Installer" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Installer" Registry key is used to store configuration information regarding the Windows Installer service. Unauthorized modifications to the Windows Installer's configuration settings may render it unavailable. This would prevent new applications with installation routines dependent on the Windows Installer from being installed. For this reason, permissions on this registry key should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Installer' Registry key should have its permission set so as to prevent unauthorized access.
The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Installer' Registry key should have its permission set so as to prevent unauthorized access.
SID's Verification

metadata.title: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies" Registry key is used to store Registry entries managed by Group Policies. If access permissions on this key are too permissive, attackers will be able to change the parameters stored under it, which could lead to security breaches being exploited in future attacks. For this reason, permissions on this registry key should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies' Registry key should have its permission set so as to prevent unauthorized access.
The 'HKLM\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Policies' Registry key should have its permission set so as to prevent unauthorized access.
SID's Verfication

metadata.title: The "HKLM\SYSTEM" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\SYSTEM" Registry key is used to store parameters used during the startup of the operating system. If access permissions on this key are too permissive, attackers will be able to make changes that could lead to security being breached at the operating system boot time. For this reason, permissions on this registry key should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HKLM\SYSTEM' Registry key should have its permission set to Administrators and SYSTEM = Full Control.
The 'HKLM\SYSTEM' Registry key should have its permission set to CREATOR OWNER = None.
The 'HKLM\SYSTEM' Registry key should have its permission set to Users = Read.
SID's Verification - Administrators, CREATOR OWNER, SYSTEM, Users

metadata.title: The "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Wmi\Security" Registry Key should have its permissions set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Wmi\Security" Registry key is used to store WMI ("Windows Management Instrumentation") security configuration parameters. If access permissions on this key are too permissive, attackers will be able to make changes that could breach WMI security. For this reason, permissions on this registry key should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Wmi\Security' Registry Key should have its permissions set to Administrators and SYSTEM = Full Control
The 'HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Control\Wmi\Security' Registry Key should have its permissions set to CREATOR OWNER = None.
SID's Verification - Administrators, SYSTEM, CREATOR OWNER.

metadata.title: The "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Hardware Profiles" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Hardware Profiles" Registry key is used to store information regarding the system hardware profiles. To prevent modifications to this information from being made with the intention of rendering the system unavailable, the permissions on this key should be set up in such a way as to block unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Hardware Profiles' Registry key should have its permission set to Administrators and SYSTEM = Full Control.
The 'HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Hardware Profiles' Registry key should have its permission set to CREATOR OWNER = None.
The 'HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Hardware Profiles' Registry key should have its permission set to Users = Read.
SID's Verification - Administrators, SYSTEM, CREATOR OWNER, Users.

metadata.title: The "HK_USERS\.DEFAULT" Registry key should have its permission set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "HK_USERS\.DEFAULT" Registry key is used to store configuration information regarding the default user profile. This information is used when no user is logged onto the system. To prevent unauthorized changes from being made to the configuration settings regarding this user profile, which could lead to security breaches, the permissions on this key should be set up in such a way as to block unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: The 'HK_USERS\.DEFAULT' Registry key should have its permission set to Administrators, SYSTEM = Full Control.
The 'HK_USERS\.DEFAULT' Registry key should have its permission set to CREATOR OWNER = None.
The 'HK_USERS\.DEFAULT' Registry key should have its permission set to Users = Read.
SID's Verification - Administrators, SYSTEM, CREATOR OWNER, Users.

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\regedt32.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\regedt32.exe" program is used to modify Registry keys' parameters and permissions. Should unauthorized users be allowed to run this program, they would be able to change the values of Registry parameters and also modify the permissions on these parameters. If any undue change is made, security may be breached, facilitating future attacks. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\regedt32.exe- Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\regedt32.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\secedit.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\secedit.exe" program is used to implement the Security Templates of the operating system and to perform analyses of the installed Security Policies. Should unauthorized users be allowed to run this program, they would be able to implement Security Templates configured in a way that could lead to security breaches being exploited in future attacks. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\secedit.exe- Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\secedit.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\at.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\at.exe" program enables system tasks to be scheduled. Through this program, a user can schedule an application to run at a specified time. In addition, it allows an application to run with administrative privileges. To prevent this program from running applications with access to sensitive information, it is recommended that NTFS permissions on this file be set in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\at.exe - Administrators e System: Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\at.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\attrib.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\attrib.exe" program is used to either enable or disable the "system", "hidden" and "compressed" attributes of a file or a directory. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he would be able to modify the attributes of files and directories on the system with the intention of obtaining access to them. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\attrib.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\attrib.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\cacls.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\cacls.exe" program is used to modify the Access Control List ("ACL") of files and directories stored on NTFS partitions. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he would be able to modify the access control lists of files and directories on the system with the intention of obtaining access to them. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\cacls.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\cacls.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\debug.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\debug.exe" program is used to access application data in computer memory. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he would be able to access sensitive information present in the computer memory at the time, such as passwords, for example. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\debug.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\debug.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\edlin.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\edlin.exe" program is used for editing MS-DOS files present on the system. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he would be able to make changes to MS-DOS files on the system. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\edlin.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\edlin.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\eventcreate.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\eventcreate.exe" is used to create events that can be written to the system's audit logs. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he would be able to generate incorrectly configured events, which could lead to many entries being written to the audit log. This might cause the computer to crash due to lack of disk space. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\eventcreate.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\eventcreate.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\drwatson.exe" and "%SystemRoot%\system32\drwtsn32.exe" files should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\drwatson.exe" and "%SystemRoot%\system32\drwtsn32.exe" programs are used to debug applications generating error messages on the system. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he would be able to access sensitive information present in the computer memory at the time, such as passwords, for example. For this reason, NTFS permissions on these files should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\drwatson.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\drwatson.exe - SID's Verification

Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\drwtsn32.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\ftp.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\ftp.exe" program is used to connect the system to a FTP server. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to access this file, he would be able to connect to FTP servers storing malicious code. This would enable this user to install malicious code on the system with the intention of breaching system security. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\ftp.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\ftp.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\netsh.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\netsh.exe" program is used to write command-line scripts capable of displaying or modifying the system's network configuration, either locally or remotely. Should unauthorized users be allowed to run this program, they would be able to make changes to the system configuration, which could lead to security breaches being exploited in future attacks. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\netsh.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\netsh.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\reg.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\reg.exe" program is used to modify Registry keys' parameters through command-line statements. Should unauthorized users be allowed to run this program, they would be able to make changes to Registry parameters, which could lead to security breaches being exploited in future attacks. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\reg.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\reg.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\regsvr32.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\regsvr32.exe" program is used to register or remove DLLs from the system. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he would be able to register DLLs containing malicious code in the system. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\regsvr32.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\regsvr32.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\sc.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\sc.exe" program is used to create, start, stop, find or remove any service of the operating system. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he would be able to use its functionalities in order to create services containing malicious code, or halt services in an attempt to interrupt the system. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\sc.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\sc.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\system32\runas.exe" file should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\system32\runas.exe" program enables programs to be executed with the privileges of another user. Should an unauthorized user be allowed to run this program, he would be able to run applications as a user with administrative privileges. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this file should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\runas.exe - Full Control permission
Collect permissions of %SystemRoot%\system32\runas.exe - SID's Verification

metadata.title: NTFS permissions on the "%SystemRoot%\Debug" directory should be set up in such a way as to prevent unauthorized access.
metadata.description: The "%SystemRoot%\Debug" directory is used to store the audit logs of the system and of the Active Directory. Should unauthorized users have access to this directory, they would be able to modify the files stored there to erase any evidence of their activities on the system. For this reason, NTFS permissions on this directory should be set up in a way that blocks unauthorized access.

criterion.comment: Collect permissions of Debug - Administrators, SYSTEM = Full Control
Collect permissions of Debug - CREATOR OWNER = None
Collect permissions of Debug - Users = Read Execute
SID's Verification - Administrators, SYSTEM, CREATOR OWNER, Users.

metadata.title: The Windows XP "Guest" account should be disabled.
metadata.description: If the "Guest" account is enabled and does not have a password, unauthorized remote access to the system will be allowed. Even when a strong password is created for the "Guest" account, loss of traceability will still be an issue since the actions performed by users logged on as Guest cannot be traced back to those responsible for them. Therefore, it is recommended to disable the "Guest" account.

criterion.comment: The Guest account must be disabled in Windows XP - User Verification

metadata.title: Only authorized users should be part of the "Backup Operators" local group.
metadata.description: Members of the "Backup Operators" group have access to the operating system files regardless of the existing NTFS permissions so that they can make backups and restores in the case of failures. This privilege should only be granted to those users who are highly trusted in order to avert unauthorized use of business information and data stored on the system.

criterion.comment: Only authorized users should be included in group Backup Operators - Members Verification

metadata.title: Only authorized users should be part of the "Network Configuration Operators" local group.
metadata.description: Members of the "Network Configuration Operators" local group are allowed to change server network configuration parameters. It is recommended that only authorized users be part of this group, to prevent attackers from making unauthorized changes to the server network configuration and rendering it unavailable.

criterion.comment: Only authorized users should be included in group Network Configuration Operators - Members Verification

metadata.title: Only authorized users should be part of the "Remote Desktop Users" local group.
metadata.description: Members of the "Remote Desktop Users" local group are allowed to log on remotely to the server. It is recommended that only authorized users be part of this group, to prevent attackers from gaining unauthorized access to the server.

criterion.comment: Only authorized users should be included in group Network Configuration Operators - Members Verification

metadata.title: Only authorized users should form part of the "Replicator" local group.
metadata.description: This group is used for specifying which users have the right to replicate files throughout the domain. File replication allows attackers either to gain access to sensitive company information or to obtain useful information for future attacks. Therefore, only authorized users should be part of this group.

criterion.comment: Only authorized users should be included in group Replicator- Members Verification

metadata.title: Only authorized users should be part of the "Administrators" local group.
metadata.description: Members of the "Administrators" group have unrestricted access to system resources. This privilege should only be granted to those authorized users who are highly trusted. Otherwise, the confidentiality, availability and integrity of business information and data stored on the system could be compromised.

criterion.comment: Only authorized users should be included in group Administrators- Members Verification

metadata.title: Only authorized users should be part of the local "HelpServicesGroup".
metadata.description: This group is used for specifying which users will have remote access to the computer in order to perform support and maintenance related tasks, such as diagnosing problems in the system. Only authorized users should be part of this group in order to prevent users with bad intentions from getting access to system information through privileges granted to this group.

criterion.comment: Only authorized users should be included in group HelpServicesGroup - Members Verification

metadata.title: Only authorized users should be part of the "Power Users" local group.
metadata.description: Members of the "Power Users" group have administrative privileges on the system, although with some restrictions. Also, this group was kept in Windows XP to ensure compatibility with applications that need the Power Users group. Members of this group are able to set up applications; make changes to the Registry; change the system time; modify the priority of processes; shut down Windows, etc. Such privileges should only be granted to those authorized users who are doubtlessly trustworthy so as to prevent the improper use of privileges granted to the group, for this could cause the unavailability of the system, among other problems.

criterion.comment: Only authorized users should be included in group Power Users - Members Verification

metadata.title: The IP address of the "Windows Update" service server should be added to the Windows XP "hosts" file.
metadata.description: The Windows XP "hosts" file statically associates the names of one or more "hosts" with an IP address. It is recommended that the host name and address of the "Windows Update" service be added, to prevent attackers from carrying out "DNS Spoofing" attacks to gain unauthorized access or to contaminate the system with viruses or "Trojan horses".

criterion.comment: The IP address of the 'Windows Update' service server should be added to the hosts file - File Verification

metadata.title: The "SNMP Service" should be disabled on the Windows XP, in case it's unnecessary.
metadata.description: The "SNMP Service" is used in the remote management of network devices, through the exchange of messages between them. This service allows users to manage the performance of network devices, which may aid in their capacity planning, as well as in the solution of potential problems. It is recommended that this service be either disabled or removed so as to prevent unnecessary usage of system resources as well as the misuse of sent messages by malicious users.

criterion.comment: Check if SNMP Service registry exists
SNMP Service must be disabled.
